caption.p: Research themes and core concepts identified within key research focussing on ‘Sensemaking’ presented for each focus level (whether the articles examined the managerial, organisational or general societal populations)

td.p: Individuals social process of making sense (or sensemaking) of new issues or information that are complex, surprising or confusing. Process is evolving and shifts over time with the introduction of new information. E.g. market information for developing strategy; technological information;
Ongoing- Ongoing process, dynamic and evolving
Construction- Sense constructed over time. Meaning of sustainability needs to be constructed and shared in a setting
Communicating- Language constructs reality. Common vocabulary enhances understanding e.g. along supply chain. Role of discourses
Categorising- Fitting new information in structures or new categories for decision-making
Shaped- Sensemaking process is shaped by others e.g. managers shape the sensemaking process of others when they make sense and set goals or strategies. Shaped by individual’s knowledge structure
Trade-offs- All issues cannot be prioritised at once. Paradox need to be understood before being managed
Interpretation- The process of translation of new information into knowledge
van der Heijden & Crammer ( 2017)
Khan ( 2018)
Fontana ( 2019)
Bien & Sassen ( 2020)
Child ( 2019)
Sense giving refers to the process of disseminating new views and shaping meaning. E.g strategy implementation
Sharing- Sense is shared through communication and action to give meaning and create a shared understanding
Communicating- Language communicates reality. Common vocabulary enhances understanding. New meme’s or narratives
Acting- Action translates meaning and develops shared understanding
Change Agents- Role of change agents in shifting action over time. A change agent is a sensemaker who’s actions and sensemaking process shape a shared view
Cyclic- Process of gradual cyclic change
Transfer- Sense transferred between actors
Influencing- An active, conscious process. Executives can influence from top down
van der Heijden & Crammer ( 2017)
Khan ( 2018)
Waddock ( 2019)

Sensemaking influenced by practical and social factors. Degree of influence may depend on individuals position in the company. E.g. of Influences: Individual influences or collective influences; negative influence of perceived hypocrisy; social circles; emotions and desire for social status; decision makers maybe more likely influenced by financial factors while also shaped by cultural social conventions. shaped by past sector issues e.g. Rana Plaza incident. Individuals connected with the environment e.g. farmers may derive meaning from it. Factors may be individual; organisational or from outside the organisation
Shaping- Factors continuously shaping sensemaking process. Individuals knowledge structure shapes the sensemaking process

Trade-offs- Actors may be aware of the negative financial payback but still proceed based on perceived elevation of their social status derived from the investment. Business expectations and moral purpose
Creative- Constructing a new meaning requires active imagination
Fontana ( 2019)
Waddock ( 2019)
Fassin et al. ( 2011)
Babua et al. ( 2020)
Tisch & Galbreath ( 2018)
Aguinis & Glavas ( 2019)
Managers must make sense of new innovations before they are willing to invest. E.g. Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)

tr.td: Change Agents- Executives as change agents

td.p: Patterns of sensemaking found to exist linked to individuals influences. e.g. opportunistic sensemaking; win–win sensemaking; hygienic sensemaking; philanthropic sensemaking

tr.td: Categorised- Patterns of sensemaking observed after decision makers have reviewed information and balanced trade-offs

td.p: “The leader as shaman has three central roles: healer, connector, and sensemaker in the service of a better world” Waddock, 2019
Leaders towards action on climate change need to recognise the need to shift, conceptualise the change and actively cultivate a new way

Redefining- Leaders can shift the discussion and culture towards sustainability and responsibility (from growth and profit). Changing values, business strategy and culture. Shaping the shift to values other than profit may be easier in SME
Leading- Leading the change through capability development, investment and sensegiving
Waddock ( 2019)
Fassin et al. ( 2011)
Organisational sensemaking shaped by mental models thereby operating in a perceived environment

Basu and Palazzo ( 2008) proposed organisational sensemaking involves three processes: (1) Cognitive (firms relationship with stakeholders and views about the external environment); (2) linguistic (explaining reasons for decisions or actions with others); and (3) conative (adopted behaviour)
Determining- Sensemaking process determines a company’s character
Communicating- Sensemaking can be demonstrated by a company’s use of language
Basu & Palazzo ( 2008)
Green & Peloza ( 2015)

p.italic: Process of Organisational Sensemaking—Making Collective Sense

td.p: Although sensemaking is completed at an individual level social relationships may lead to community level sense. Organisational sensemaking occurs through a process involving change agents, communication and action. A shared meaning is constructed through social interaction – colleagues come to see their environment in a common way
Enactment- Perception and action. Approaches for operationalizing sense giving–pragmatic strategy (within goals) or systemic strategy (within systems and policy) (van Der Heijden et al., 2010)
Change agents- Mediators in translating company sense
Communicating- Social interactions and communications share sense. Sense can also be shared across platforms based on issues
Sharing- A shared meaning is constructed through social interaction. Collective sense shared through community
Action- Action driven sensemaking. Shared view created through action. Beliefs shape actions and actions shape beliefs
Tisch & Galbreath ( 2018)
van Der Heijden et al. ( 2010)
Štumberger & Golob ( 2016)
Benn et al. ( 2013)
Selsky & Parker ( 2011)
Dwyer & Hardy ( 2016)
Sensemaking influenced by practical and social factors including experience

tr.td: Shaping- Factors shaping the sensemaking process dependent on ecological embeddedness and degree of experience in similar situation

td.p: Patterns of sensemaking found to exist linked to individuals influences
